title: What is a Graph?
contentText: A graph is a data structure consisting of vertices (nodes) and edges (connections) between them. It models relationships and networks.

title: Graph Structure and Properties
contentText: Graphs can be directed or undirected, weighted or unweighted. Edges represent relationships between vertices.

title: Types of Graphs
contentText: Undirected Graph, Directed Graph, Weighted Graph, and Multigraph are common graph types for different modeling needs.

title: Graph Use Cases
contentText: Graphs are used in social networks, route planning, recommendation engines, dependency graphs, and network topology.

title: Advantages of Graphs
contentText: Graphs are powerful for representing complex relationships and running algorithms like shortest path, connectivity, and centrality.

title: Example Applications
contentText: Examples include maps, internet page linking, knowledge graphs, and fraud detection networks.
